 Arab Republic of Egypt Second Social Fund Project Staff Appraisal Report 1. BACKGROUND AND ASSESSMENT OF THE FIRST PHASE A. INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND 1.1 In response to a difficult economic situation caused by falling oil prices and the Gulf War, Egypt embarked on a broad economic adjustment program with support from the World Bank and the IMF. The main stabilization goals have been met and provide a basis for sustainable economic growth. The principal problems which still persist are high levels of poverty and unemployment. Between 20-30 percent of Egyptians are estimated to live in poverty, and a recent survey found the unemployment rate, when adjusted for underemployment, to be close to 21 percent. Eighty-five percent of the unemployed are between 19 and 29 years of age, and most are recent graduates. 1.2 The high level of poverty is not just a social and equity issue: those factors which cause widespread poverty also contribute substantially to the lack of broad-based growth. Egypt has the potential to develop a dynamic and forward-looking small enterprise sector which could lead to both broad-based employment generation and poverty reduction. Egypt also has age-old social structures and community groups which are close to the people (particularly the poor) and can play a strong role in the country's economic development. Broad based economic growth that harnesses the energies of Egypt's small entrepreneurs and community organizations can also help reduce the attraction of extremist political movements, thus contributing to political and social stability. B. SOCIAL FUND: EVALUATION 1993-95 AND PROPOSALS FOR FUTURE StISTAINABILITY 1.3 Social Fund for Development (SFD): The SFD was set up in 1991 at the height of the Gulf crisis. Its activities between 1993-96 (referred to as Phase I while Phase 11 refers to 1997-2000) was supported by many donors including IDA through Credit No. C2276-EGT approved by the Board on June 21, 1991. This credit is expected to be fully disbursed by December 31, 1996. The SFD was conceived with three objectives: (a) to help reduce poverty through supporting employment generation and community development efforts; (b) to help mitigate the possible negative impact of the Economic Reform and Structural Adjustment Program (ERSAP); and (c) to provide help to the Gulf returnees. These objectives were to be achieved through five programs: Public Works Program (PWP) to support labor intensive construction projects; Community Development Program (CDP) including support for microenterprise and community based social services; Enterprise Development Program (EDP) to help new and on-going small enterprises; Labor Mobility Program (LMP) to help labor adjust to economic reform; and Institutional Development Program (IDP) to support the SFD secretariat as well as poverty monitoring through surveys and studies. A review of SFD performance by the Government (SFD-Mission Beyond 1996, October 1994) concluded that the SFD has been very successful. A more recent evaluation was done by the World Bank based on information collected using the following methods: (a) extensive in-depth field visits; (b) impact survey in five govemorates; and (c) review of administrative data from the SFD and its partners. The World Bank evaluation confirmed the previous positive assessment of 1994, though it found that some areas needed improvement. The evaluation findings are summarized below. 1.4 The SFD met its first objective. It was able to create 50,000-70,000 jobs per year, i.e. almost 25 percent of annual non-agriculture jobs created. The SFD did this without crowding out the private sector, primarily by supporting small enterprises which previously had no access to banks. The second objective was to be met by helping workers made redundant through public enterprise restructuring or privatization. This objective was only partially met as the pace of privatization/restructuring was slower than expected. The SFD also partly met the third objective by creating employment opportunities for Gulf returnees. The SFD met its employment creation objectives with annual expenditures equivalent to only 0.2 percent of GDP, or about 6 percent of annual donor flows to Egypt. This job-creation cost compares favorably with other countries, based on data from various units within the World Bank (see Table 1.1). SFD's achievements are given in Annex 5, and an assessment of its various programs follows.

The range of activities supported by the CDP includes: (a) social services such as literacy classes, health care, family planning, etc.; (b) micro-enterprises to increase the income of the poorest households; and (c) community centers which provide a base for social services and recreational activities. In the course of its operations, the CDP has adopted a very participatory approach and is also supporting the development of NGOs. The second issue is the lack of market orientation for the CDP microenterprise and training activities: the CDP has sometimes provided training for skills which are saturated or have no market. This problem will be addressed by closely monitoring local market conditions before approving support for enterprises (Annex 2, para.32). 1.7 Enterprise Development Program (EDP): The objective of the EDP is to help create employment through support for new and existing small enterprises by providing a package of technical assistance, training and credit. The difference between the CDP and the EDP lending activities is that the average CDP loan is US$500 and credit is extended through NGOs, while the EDP's average loan is US$4,000 and credit is extended through banks. Bank lending is complemented by technical assistance and is provided through NGOs. Banks take the full commercial risk of their lending and hence have sole loan decision authority. The program has disbursed over LE 700 million to intermediaries for on-lending and has spent substantial additional resources to develop and deliver technical assistance packages. Over 60,000 sub-loans are outstanding, and 25 percent of the borrowers are female. 1.8 Given current interest rates to final borrowers, as well as the spreads that the banks can charge, the interest rate on a loan to an existing small business is slightly above inflation (spread of 3 percent) while the interest rate on a loan to a new business is slightly below inflation (spread of 4 percent). Interest rates to final borrowers are reviewed on a yearly basis. Repayment rates appear good, although this conclusion is based on limited data as many sub-loans are still in the grace period. The banks started their first repayments to the EDP last summer and these funds will be re-lent. About 40 percent of loans were for start-up enterprises and thus, the EDP program provided access to the banking system for borrowers who otherwise would not have received a loan. In total, 120,000 permanent jobs were created (measured as a job still in existence one year after its creation). Forty-three percent of loans are for small industry, 21 percent for services, 23 percent for agriculture and animal production, and 11 percent for trade. Unemployed graduates are a priority target group of the EDP. His small business in the market area of Aswan is thriving: he employs ten people making clothing. SFD support has helped this determined individual, and through him helped also his ten employees. 1.9 The EDP was designed primarily as a "job-creation" mechanism to assist entrepreneurs and to disburse loans quickly and efficiently without much regard for issues affecting sustainability of the SFD itself. It has successfully helped thousand of borrowers while operating under a set of (often conflicting) donor demands and constraints. The EDP in effect acts as a successful wholesale small business support and finance agency, delivering loans to small businesses through banks and delivering business services through NGOs. During the assessment of Phase I of the program, it was agreed that the issue of sustainability needs to be addressed in Phase 11. This would require that: (a) SFD on-lending to banks carries an interest rate sufficient to maintain the value of SFD funds in real terms; (b) the cost of the services provided by SFD staff is recovered in the long-term, directly or indirectly, from the banks/beneficiaries; (c) the banks have a sufficient spread to cover their costs, including an allowance for default; and (d) the EDP, while maintaining its social objectives, is managed as a self-standing commercial program. A Task Force including SFD staff, banks and donor representatives has been established to identify means of achieving these goals, and it has issued a preliminary report which has been made available to the World Bank and other donors. Thefindings of the Task Force has been developed into a business plan which was discussed during negotiations; its execution has been included as a covenant in the Credit and Project Agreement (para. 5.2). 1.10 Labor Mobility Program (LMP): The objectives of this program were to provide workers in restructured or privatized public sector enterprises with financial assistance, training and placement services. The original

Since the Government's privatization program moved considerably more slowly than was expected, the demand for LMP activities was limited and donors agreed to reduce the program to US$40 million (with the funds being reallocated to other programs), implicitly reducing the target to 20,000 workers. So far the program has assisted 3,000 workers in three enterprises and is currently working on assisting an additional 10,000 workers in seven enterprises. 1.11 Institutional Development Program (IDP): The IDP's objectives included support for (a) SFD management; and (b) poverty monitoring in collaboration with researchers and CAPMAS (Central Agency for Public Mobilization and Statistics). The management of the SFD has been efficient (overhead costs are 6 percent of disbursements). CAPMAS/SFD completed a survey (living standards measurement) in 1993 which provides data for poverty analysis. The survey includes data to update price indices and the GDP deflator. 1.12 Gender Targeting: The SFD targets women as a special group for assistance: 25 percent of EDP loan beneficiaries were women, which is higher than would be expected given Egypt's entrepreneurship patterns, and compares favorably to other enterprise development activities which achieve a 10 percent target of support to women. Over 60 percent of CDP beneficiaries were women, including a third of the micro-entrepreneurs. C. SPECIAL FEATURES OF THE SOCIAL FUND 1.13 Managerial Autonomy: The SFD's managerial autonomy in terms of decision making, procurement and disbursements is a major factor behind its success. The Board of Directors (BOD) and its Executive Committee (EC) set policy and leave day to day management to the Managing Director. 1.14 Role of NGOs: NGOs play a prominent role in SFD programs, particularly in the areas of community development (CDP) and enterprise development (EDP). Up to July 1995, NGOs managed LE 100 million out of LE 192 million approved for CDP sub-projects (52 percent), and LE 609 million out of LE 1,406 million approved for EDP sub-projects (43 percent). Thus, the SFD has also been able to attain its objective of working in partnership with NGOs. NGOs provide an essential link to communities and are able to articulate community concerns well. Their role will become even more prominent in Phase II. Initially the SFD had to rely primarily on government sponsored NGOs, but it has been able to broaden the range of NGOs it deals with and thus to broaden its appeal to communities. Close collaboration with the main religious NGOs as well as with the Egyptian Red Crescent and the Family Planning Association has helped the SFD to work with smaller NGOs and community groups through the use of a mentor system. Many of these smaller NGOs are now working independently, mostly in poor rural areas (NGO-SFD relations are discussed in Annexes 1, 2 and 3 in the context of various programs). 1.15 Role of Donors: Donors have played a major role in supporting the SFD in the past. This strong support can be attributed to donor interest in supporting Egypt's poor and unemployed and also to the SFD's demonstrated efficiency. SFD effectiveness has been recognized by many donors who provided funding, including the European Union, Denmark, France, Germany, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, the Arab Fund, the Kuwait Fund, the Abu Dhabi Fund, China and India. Many donors have pooled their funds with the World Bank Group during Phase 1. Others have worked in parallel. Without this vigorous and sustained donor support, SFD's initial progress would not have been possible. D. The World Bank has taken a broad based approach in the social sectors and has supported projects in basic health and education. THE PROPOSED PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECrIVES 2.1 The project objectives are to help: (a) create jobs through support of small enterprises and labor intensive works, and (b) support community infrastructure and services in partnership with NGOs and local groups. These objectives would be accomplished through building on the strengths of the first phase of the SFD. The issues raised in paragraphs 1.5 to 1.9 will be addressed to assure that the SFD is more sustainable, more highly targeted and more efficient during Phase II. B. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 2.2 The proposed second phase of the SFD will include the following programs: (a) Small-scale Labor Intensive Works Program: The SLWP will build on the public works program, with an increased focus on community partnership and targeting. Sub-projects will continue to be executed in close cooperation with Governorates. the local branches of the relevant technical Ministries and the concerned community. (b) Community Development Program: The CDP would build on the current program and continue to focus on (i) community and NGO participation, (ii) capacity building and (iii) targeting of women, the poor, and the unemployed. CDP sub-projects will continue to be executed in partnership with NGOs and the beneficiary communities, with involvement of local authorities at the planning stage. (c) Enterprise Development Program: The EDP has evolved into a credit program providing loans to banks for on-lending to entrepreneurs and a technical assistance program for entrepreneurs through NGOs. During implementation of Phase II, the EDP would be restructured according to a business plan (agreed with the World Bank) designed to assure long-term sustainability. (d) Human Resource Development Program: The HRDP would build on the public enterprise labor mobility program but extend its mandate to support labor mobility in private sector companies affected by trade liberalization. The program would also provide support on a matching grant basis to small enterprises that wish to train their workers. Grants would be transparent and would be larger for skills with higher mobility. The labor mobility program would be executed in partnership with the enterprise concerned, while training services would be provided under contract by the private sector. (e) Institutional Development Program: The IDP would support SFD management as well as poverty monitoring and other studies linked to poverty and social safety nets. During Phase 11, decentralization of functions would increase through transfer of responsibility for programs to SFD's regional offices when feasible. This would allow even closer association with local Governments than is now the case.

IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS Operating Procedures of SFD 2.5 The project will be implemented by SFD in accordance with its established procedures. These are stated in its Operational Manual, which was developed in consultation with the Government and donors. The mission found the manual to be acceptable though occasional revisions will be required to take into account changing conditions on the ground. During negotiations the borrower and SFD gave assurances that the statutes, by-laws and operating procedures of SFD will remain acceptable to the World Bank Group at all times (para. 5.2). 2.6 The SFD executes projects in partnership with development partners - Govemorates, NGOs, commercial banks and Ministries. Proposals for a wide range of activities are submitted to one of the SFD programs by partner agencies. For example, a proposal could involve several rural roads and water supply systems for a particular region. The activities, each of which is referred to as a sub-project, would be executed by SFD in cooperation with the proposing agency. The package of proposals (called a sub-programn) could include activities such as a waste water plant in one village, a road providing access to a second and a community center in a third. Individual proposals are screened to assure that they do not replicate activities undertaken by other agencies or include activities with harmful social or environmental side-effects. Sub-program proposals as a whole are then subjected to economic and environmental analysis. Full economic and environmental analysis is required when sub-program size exceeds US$500,000. Due to their small size, it is not possible to carry out this level of economic and environmental analysis for most sub-project proposals. In these cases, a screening process is used to determine cost- effectiveness. 2.7 Sub-project Cycle. The SFD initiates and accepts sub-project proposals submitted by sponsoring agencies (SA) to any ten of the regional or six satellite offices. Selection of proposals is based on two sets of criteria. The first is contained in guidelines focusing on regional allocations which are established in the Operational Manual. These regional allocations are based on the distribution of poverty and are made for public works and community development sub-projects only. The Community Development Program (CDP), an integral part of SFD was designed to finance improvements in: (i) productive activities focusing on income and employment generation; and (ii) social development activities to improve the delivery of essential services to poor communities. These objectives have been achieved to a large extent, with CDP evolving to respond to community needs, in some instances by utilizing innovative approaches. Through its integrated project activities, CDP has infused communities with an enhanced level of social awareness and self-esteem, especially women. CDP represents an important vehicle for mobilizing the energies and resources of community groups, local governments, NGOs, and the private sector by using a participatory approach, thus leading to more sustainable projects. Stimulating community involvement and active NGO participation in Egypt can be regarded as a dramatic transformation and departure from the reliance of communities on the public sector for the provision of services. The promotion of self-help activities can be seen as the cornerstone of CDP projects and an effective mechanism for addressing poverty alleviation. 2. CDP's flexibility and decentralized approach allows it to exploit the diverse strengths of different actors, to benefit from the geographical coverage that multiple organizations might be able to provide, and to finance projects simultaneously in multiple sectors. 3. This report draws upon field visits, interviews, data, and various documents collected in the field. A. Outputs of CDP Operations 4. Community Participation. The active involvement of community groups is evident in CDP projects, where they are involved in project selection and design. Once communities have developed a sense of ownership of a project, they have proven to be more willing to share in its financing and to ensure that it is well maintained and properly operated. This statement has been clearly represented in a myriad of CDP projects in the governorate of Qena, especially in the Toad project where the community was willing to mobilize resources to implement projects as well as provide contributions aimed at assisting marginalized families attain basic services. 5. Provision of Basic Social Services. CDP projects have been able to distribute resources to communities previously underserved by government agencies or private-sector organizations. CDP activities focus on the provision of health, education and training services to poor population groups. Health activities represent 21 percent of CDP's overall project portfolio. Activities eligible for funding by CDP are: (i) provision of supplies, equipment and personnel for primary health care centers; (ii) immunization campaigns; (iii) mother and child nutrition programs; and (iv) provision of supplies and equipment for child care centers. Funds were allocated to rehabilitate and equip 46 clinics, conduct 569 health awareness campaigns and train 820 health personnel. Beneficiaries interviewed in upper Egypt and Alexandria, confirmed the need for the provision of such services and the unavailability of alternatives. 6. Education and training comprised 42 percent of CDP activities. Activities eligible for funding include: (i) short-term literacy programs; (ii) practical training programs; and (iii) community organization and leadership training. Due to its success in responding to unmet demand, 35 percent of the education budget has gone towards financing adult illiteracy projects. The Education and Training component has helped rehabilitate 187 classrooms, establish 9,123 illiteracy classes, and train 9,241 individuals to teach illiteracy classes. In the area of vocational training and related training, 28 training workshops have been equipped, and 8,369 individuals have benefited from such activities. Communities expressed satisfaction with the education and training services provided through CDP projects, and requested a continuation of such services. 7. Discussions with communities in upper Egypt have indicated that vocational training has also played an important role in developing skills of young people and afforded them employment opportunities. 8. Employment Generation. Creating employment rapidly has been a primary objective of CDP projects. The extension of credit, construction of schools, latrines or health centers stimulated demand for local industry and absorbed a portion of the labor force in the selected communities. Communities visited in upper Egypt emphasized the importance of employment generation activities that have materialized as a result of CDP funded projects. 10. Productive family activities have financed new and existing income generating schemes, involving the establishment of small revolving funds for self-help productive activities and related training in management and productive skills. CDP activities have targeted and responded to needs which reflect the integral role of women in poverty alleviation efforts in Egypt. As productive agents, women's participation in income generating activities represent a crucial part of the survival strategy of poor households. Women have increasingly shifted away from traditional agricultural into commercial activities, either in the selling of agricultural products or in trading of urban goods and services. The status of women and their empowerment in their communities has been dramatically enhanced through the use of a participatory approach and the provision of social and productive services. CDP activities involve women representatives on the board of local committees. To raise the productivity of women's activities, CDP has expanded access to basic education and training, credit and improved infrastructure such as markets and roads. To date 50 percent of CDP projects have financed projects of these types to low-income women. 24. Apart from their increasingly important role in the economic well-being of poor families, women have traditionally played the central role in the development of Egypt's human resource base. The EDP is in an unique position to become sustainable and to achieve operational and possibly financial costs coverage over the next few years by gradually charging fees for its services. In order to achieve sustainability of the EDP and also enhance the prospects of a sustainable SFD operation, the following basic premises were adopted by the SFD: * The EDP will use its current achievements (outstanding portfolio and beneficiaries reached) as an important basis to develop sustainability now and in the future, which will go beyond the lifetime of Phase 11. * Sustainability cannot be achieved overnight; a medium term time frame of two to four years is needed to enable the organization to cover its costs. * To achieve its development objectives, continued donor funding is required in the following areas: (i) funding (on a decreasing basis) for the EDP overhead during the process of transition; this funding could be based on EDP meeting certain performance standards that are raised over time; (ii) funding to enable the organization to fulfill its socio-economic development mandate through transparent subsidies based on performance contracts; and (iii) funding (on a decreasing matching grant basis) to enhance the viability, efficiency and outreach of EDP's intermediaries (banks and NGOs) because the EDP's viability depends upon that of its intermediaries. * The organization will have a capital basis that is sufficient to serve its projected tasks now and in the future; an initial capitalization of no less than LE 250 million is required. III. Redesign current features of the EDP 16. At the time of design and implementation of EDP, the main (donor and government) emphasis was on disbursement in order to create jobs without regard to sustainability. In the future, the following characteristics of the EDP as it is currently operating may inhibit sustainability and hence should be addressed:
 ANNEX 3 Page 5 of 7 17. Selection of Intermediaries. Currently, public sector banks are the main intermediaries for on-lending. Their performance varies widely and they did not intrinsically change the way they do business. This is especially apparent in the fact that they still require high collateral and that repayments schedules do not incorporate cash flow dynamics. Banks will be the main income generator for the independent and sustainable EDP program, and they will only continue "buying the EDP services and funds" if small business lending represents an attractive opportunity for them. In this context, banks should be free to determine the price of on-lending without getting a license to pass on costs of inefficiency to the final borrower (see below). Banks may also require institutional support to help them become better and more efficient small business lenders. 18. More flexibility in Targeting. It is strongly recommended that EDP reviews its targeting mechanisms. Entrepreneurs that start or manage new and existing businesses do not necessarily have to be very poor or come from certain disadvantaged groups such as graduates or unemployed public sector employees. The main objective is that new businesses are created or that existing small businesses grow. Also, international experience indicates that the unemployed do not necessarily make good entrepreneurs. More flexible target requirements will lead to more potential entrepreneurs whose businesses will create jobs possibly employing number of disadvantaged groups. 20. More flexible Sub-loan design. Sub-loan terms and conditions should focus on enhancing flexibility to better meet the entrepreneurs' needs and to ensure viability of intermediaries. Attention should be given to: (i) the definition of micro and small businesses, taking into account sectoral differences; (ii) broadening the permitted purposes (uses) of the sub-loans; (iii) increasing the loan ceiling (for instance up to 10 percent of the banks' SFD portfolio) to accommodate growth of existing EDP clients and to allow for increased demand for larger loans of new clients; loan ceilings could be changed yearly according to inflation; (iv) varying grace periods and maturities according to the project cash flow and purpose of the loan; (v) pricing of the sub-loans according to project risks and costs of making the sub-loan; (vi) providing incentives to banks to accept more flexible collateral; and (vii) recognizing subsidies whenever to ensure they are transparent to banks, entrepreneurs, and donors.  ANNEX 4: HUMAN RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM A. Background and Phase I - Labor Mobility Program Background I. In recent years, the growth rate of employment in Egypt has not kept pace with labor force growth leading to increased unemployment. A recent survey indicates that the unemployment rate was about 20.5 percent in 1993, and more than 80 percent of those unemployed were graduates from university and technical secondary schools, whose levels of skills were not relevant to the market needs. This skill mismatch was largely due to the poor quality of both training and education. 2. Egypt has a large number of public sector enterprises, and many of which continue to make losses, partially due to over-staffing. Research shows that the level of redundant workers in public sector enterprises ranges from 30 to 40 percent. Based on the results, it has been projected that these redundant workers would be laid off as many more public sector enterprises are expected to be privatized in coming years. 3. In order to absorb these redundant workers and to provide job opportunities to unemployed graduates, the expansion of the private sector is indispensable. Domestic enterprises will soon face strong competitive pressures from the trade liberalization resulting from Egypt's accession to the World Trade Organization and its Free Trade Treaty with the European Union. Phase I - Labor Mobility Program 4. The main objective of Phase I of Labor Mobility Program (LMP) was to focus on redeployment of workers in public sector enterprises through technical assistance. The technical assistance included: (i) upgrading workers' skills through retraining; and (ii) preparing workers for alternative jobs. In addition, the program also aimed to provide retraining and placement of unemployed graduates. 5. In order to facilitate labor mobility of public enterprises, LMP worked with three public sector enterprises, and SFD provided assistance to 3,000 workers of these companies. For example, in Alexandria Shipyard, LMP helped in retraining redundant workers. Those workers were retrained as certified welders, and their productivity increased as much as 300 percent. The cost for retraining was LE 3,500 per worker. 6. Currently, SFD has been authorized to work on the labor mobility programs of additional seven public sector enterprises (total of 10 enterprises) from January 1996. The SFD will assist public sector enterprises through programs such as retraining, early retirement, spin-offs of its business, and self-employment. The total number of workers receiving SFD assistance by the end of 1996 is about to be 10,000 at an estimated cost of LE 110 million. 7. To match workers to employment opportunities, LMP implemented 15 demand-led training projects through private sector/union owned training facilities. Primarily, the training institutions identified jobs and then requested SFD help to train workers for these jobs thus, all graduates are employed. In these activities, SFD finances the fees for trainees and the cost of up-grading the training modules and equipment in both public and private training centers. These projects helped place about 2,000 unemployed graduates in permanent job opportunities at an average cost of LE 1,500 per trainee. B. Phase 11 - Labor Mobility Program Phase 11 Objectives 8. During Phase 11, LMP would be revamped into a broader Human Resources Development Program which would assist: (a) labor mobility in public enterprise being restructured or privatized; (b) redeployment of workers in

To achieve these objectives, the program would expand the mandate of LMP to support labor mobility of private sector enterprises. Phase 11 - Description 9. In order to achieve the above objectives, Phase 11 of the program will have two components: (a" Labor Mobility Component 10. This component will assist labor mobility activities in public sector enterprises and in private enterprises facing competitive pressures due to trade liberalization. Labor mobility would include an early retirement program (not IDA funded), financial assistance to start new businesses, and retraining of redundant workers. A major activity of this component would be retraining of redundant workers in public sector enterprises, so that it can help these workers to find new jobs in private sectors. The main areas of training would be marketing, maintenance, quality control, and technical skills, which are essential to expand their businesses. This component will not finance stipends of trainees and salaries of trainers. In order to prioritize the area of training, the component would support the periodical informal labor market survey (twice a year to be undertaken under contract by a private research institutes) to assess the recent skill requirements in the regional market. 12. Some Concepts 2. Impact monitoring is defined here to include three types of monitoring: (i) implementation progress monitoring; (ii) outcome monitoring; and (iii) targeting effectiveness monitoring. These concepts are discussed below. * Implementation Progress Monitoring. Implementation progress monitoring tracks the extent to which the intended goods and services (inputs and outputs) are being delivered. * Outcome Monitoring. Outcome monitoring tracks the extent to which the development objectives which underlie the delivery of the specific goods and services are being achieved. * Targeting Effectiveness Monitoring. Targeting effectiveness monitoring tracks the extent to which the groups and individuals intended to benefit are actually benefiting. B. Significance of Systematic Monitoring and Targeting 3. Importance of Monitoring. The main purpose of monitoring the implementation progress and outcomes of SFD interventions is to be able to make adjustments in design and implementation as warranted. Effective monitoring is a useful management tool and can provide early warning signals about impending problems. 4. There are two levels at which it is important to monitor SFD operations: (a) at the level of the SFD headquarters; and (b) at the level of the subprojects undertaken by SFD's sponsoring agencies. Monitoring the overall functioning of the SFD secretariat can highlight opportunities for improving its efficiency (e.g., increasing operational speed), and informing SFD policy (e.g., the need to focus resources on Governorates with high poverty/unemployment indices that may have received lower resources than their allocation). The importance of monitoring the progress of subprojects undertaken by sponsoring agencies emerges from the fact that SFD differs from traditional projects in that it does not design or implement subprojects itself, but relies, instead, on a large number of small and widely dispersed organizations to do so; monitoring the extent to which the various activities of these organizations are consistent with the intended use of the resources allocated to them is critical. 5. Importance of Targeting. Given scarce resources and the unlimited needs of the poor and the unemployed, the chances of SFD achieving its goal of providing an effective safety net for the poor and the unemployed would be enhanced by improving the targeting of its resources to these groups. 6. Cost of Monitoring. Monitoring has definite costs in terms of staff time and the budget. But, these costs should be weighed against its longer term benefits. While no precise calculations have been made here of the cost of the proposed monitoring system, three factors indicate that these costs are not likely to place an undue burden on the SFD headquarters. First, SFD's existing monitoring system already systematically records and regularly updates information on SFD approvals and disbursements, the total number of beneficiaries, and the number of temporary and permanent jobs created by each SFD component. Hence, the marginal cost of compiling the additional information that the proposed monitoring system entails should be relatively low. Second, the responsibility for collecting the required information on Implementation Progress will vest with the sponsoring agencies -- not SFD. The sponsoring agencies will report this information regularly to SFD which will record the information in its database after spot checks on its accuracy. SFD has also created complementary relationships between the objectives of the fund and those of line agencies and the final beneficiaries. This in turn has catalyzed beneficiary participation in decision making and unleashed the latent energy of people, leading to a more sustainable development approach in comparison with the more traditional project approach. Specifically, the involvement of beneficiaries in consultation, cost sharing and decision making has improved the outcomes of sub-projects by: (a) ensuring that sub- projects are relevant to beneficiary needs; and (b) generating commitment to sustaining project activities. 2. Beneficiary participation strategies are imperative to ensure the sustainability of the a large number of dispersed sub-projects. These include: (i) transferring participatory approaches to government agencies and intermediaries; (ii) decentralizing management; (iii) sharing information with stakeholders; (vi) training staff in participatory approaches; and (v) training beneficiaries. Each approach is discussed in detail below. (a) Transferring Participatory Approaches to Government Agencies and Intermediaries. Incorporating mechanisms to transfer the participatory elements to regular government ministries, as well as other sponsoring agencies (i.e., NGOs) is being pursued by the fund. During Phase 11, SFD is planning a training program for ministry staff in management information during sub-project appraisal and execution. Given the important role delegated to NGOs/intermediaries, SFD has allocated resources for assessing and strengthening their capacities, in terms of beneficiary representation and development effectiveness. NGOs are evaluated during appraisal of a sub- project, on the basis of criteria which indicate where training might be required. In response to the training needs required by NGOs, a one year pilot program is being initiated in six governorates to benefit twenty NGOs with the goal of building their institutional capacity. (b) Decentralizing Management. The existence of ten regional and six satellite' offices facilitates the implementation of a participatory approach throughout the sub-project cycle by allowing for close community consultation. This has fostered a collaborative decision making process and forged links between community organizations engaged in joint development activities. (c) Sharing Information with Stakeholders. The SFD employs a variety of mechanisms and strategies aimed at fostering a participatory dialogue, which include information sharing and consultative sessions and workshops with stakeholders (governorates, NGOs, and communities) during the promotion, and appraisal stages. In addition, these efforts are complemented by beneficiary assessment, sub-project ex-post evaluations, and participatory rural appraisal methods designed to evaluate and constantly improve project design in order to target the intended beneficiaries more precisely, involve them in the sub-project cycle, and define the characteristics of the least advantaged groups. (d) Training Staff in Participatory Approaches. Involving staff (NGOs, and religious leaders) who have worked with beneficiaries, has demonstrated success in designing and implementing sub-projects. Familiarity with the cultural milieu, ability to communicate with the poor are assets which allow the fund to operate more effectively. Fund staff receive training in participatory intervention methods in order to enable them to become more responsive to the needs of the beneficiaries. During Phase 11 of the SFD, efforts should be made to introduce an incentive structure that rewards staff for adhering to participatory procedures. (e) Training Beneficiaries In the case where beneficiaries do not have the requisite skills to prioritize, and/or prepare proposals and/or technical designs, SFD provides technical assistance to help beneficiary groups prepare The number of regional and satellite offices is not expected to increase over the life of the project.
 ANNEX 8 Page 2 of 3 proposals and carry out technical design. In such instances extensive training and institutional strengthening programs are provided to the stakeholders, with an emphasis on local planning, prioritization of needs, management, monitoring, as well as operations and maintenance. This empowers beneficiaries to identify and prioritize their needs to develop strategies to meet them. Targeting 3. Given it's mandate to mitigate the impact of economic adjustment on the poor and marginalized groups, the SFD has fulfilled its aim at extensive coverage across the country. Priority target areas were selected based on a targeting map prepared by SFD in 1992. The amounts of financing extended were weighed according to the relative poverty rankings of each governorate. Data generated from the Central Agency for Public Mobilization and Statistics (CAPMAS) has been used to occasionally supplement the original poverty map. Efforts are underway for SFD to update it's poverty map and targeting mechanism in order to reflect the evolving nature of SFD, and the current patterns of poverty in Egypt. 4. Currently, SFD's geographic and sectoral resource allocations reflects both a demand and supply driven nature. It does not identify potential sub-projects but responds to proposals generated by beneficiaries or intermediaries. Thus, those groups with the greatest ability to generate proposals are better positioned to benefit from SFD funds, though typically they are not the neediest. SFD is attempting to reconcile the discrepancies between demand and supply by streamlining targeting and promotion efforts in order to better respond to the poor. During Phase I, SFD's activities focused on the disbursement of funds, and targeting was relegated to a secondary role. Therefore, except for a recent pilot survey, limited data exists on SFD's targeting effectiveness. This situation is quickly being revised, and staff at the fund are in the process of remedying this short-coming. Data on targeting will be collected during promotional campaigns as well as desk and field appraisals using participatory approaches. 5. Pilot Survey-Targeting. A recent pilot survey conducted in two Governorates (Minya and Beni Suef) to assess the effectiveness of SFD's targeting mechanism was undertaken by the Project and Planning Department. This was done to test some of the recommended Beneficiary Profile indicators in collaboration with the Community Development Program and the Enterprise Development Program. Seven sub-projects (three in Beni-Suef and four in Minya) out of 19 sub-projects were chosen based on the accessibility of sub-project sites. Varying numbers of districts in which these sub-projects were operating were chosen for each sub-project. A sample of 5 percent of the beneficiaries (100 percent of the beneficiaries, where the total number of beneficiaries was small) was chosen in each selected district for each sub-project (amounting to a total sample of 903 beneficiaries). Beneficiary Profile data were also collected for a sample of beneficiaries for two additional sub-projects (sample of 583 beneficiaries). 6. The results of the CDP pilot highlighted that a large segment of beneficiaries in the literacy program in Beni-Suef were women (54 percent); 68 percent of the beneficiaries of the Giza literacy program were illiterate and the rest were drop-outs as opposed to 63 percent illiterate and 37 drop-outs. 42 percent of beneficiaries participating in the Productive Families Project had assets of less than L.E.500 (US$150); and six of the 9 projects had beneficiaries roughly of whom came from households with 7 or more members; and 20 percent of the beneficiaries in the seven sub-project did not have access to sanitation facilities, indicating they were very poor. 7. The methodology used for determining the beneficiaries from the Enterprise Development Program (EDP), was taken from a total of 18 EDP sponsoring agencies that had been contracted and had received disbursements from SFD. A sample of 8 agencies were chosen, A random sample of 10 percent of the loan recipients were selected which amounted to 347 out of a total of 3480 loan recipients. The results indicated that in several governorates, more than half the beneficiaries were women, and in other govemorates, most of the beneficiaries were located in rural areas. In select cases, 33 percent of the beneficiaries had been unemployed prior to receiving the EDP loan. 8. The above information would require complementary data collected through BA, or a Needs and Capacity Study. Nevertheless, in broad terms the results from the pilot indicated that specific SFD sub-projects are reaching individuals who could be classified as "needy", suggesting that SFD's current targeting mechanism could be achieving its intended beneficiaries.
 ANNEX 8 Page 3 of 3 9. Given the evolving nature of SFD, target groups will have to be redefined to guide the design of each of SFD's components. The existing socio-economic data which focuses on the governorate level needs to be narrowed to the district, village, or community level, thereby enabling SFD to concentrate resources on those specific locations that have the highest poverty/unemployment rates. 10. Priority Ranking. Assigning a three-layered targeting and ranking methodology for the selection of sub- projects for financing by SFD is being explored. This methodology used in other social funds, assigns priority ranks of 1, 2 etc.. to: (a) intended target groups; (b) different types of sub-projects; and (c) the Governorates. The target group rank would be regarded as the overriding rank; if two sub-projects had the same target group rank, the rank for the sub-project type would determine which sub-project is chosen for financing. It two sub-projects had the same target group rank and the same sub-project type rank, the rank for the governorate would determine the choice of the sub-project for financing. The objective of the ranking exercise is to learn how the fund is doing in meeting community needs. In addition to the above recommendation, it is imperative for SFD to apply targeting criteria throughout the sub-project cycle, starting with promotion through implementation and supervision. During each stage, using participatory methods for collecting data will also allow for a diagnostic self-assessment.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Second Social Fund Project are to help: 1) create jobs through support of small enterprises and labor intensive works; and 2) support community infrastructure and services in partnership with nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) and local groups.
